questionContent.body: Which of the following is true about scalar functions

questionOptions.body: They are used only in triggers

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Scalar functions return a single value and are often used in expressions.

questionContent.body: Which keyword is used to create a function

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: CREATE FUNCTION defines a new SQL function.

questionContent.body: Which keyword is used to exit from a stored procedure early

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: RETURN is used to exit and optionally return a value.

questionContent.body: Which SQL keyword is used to create a stored procedure

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: CREATE PROCEDURE is used to define a stored procedure.

questionContent.body: Which statement is used to remove an index in SQL Server

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: DROP INDEX is used to remove an index from a table.

questionContent.body: Which of the following types of indexes is used to enforce uniqueness

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: A UNIQUE index ensures that all values in the indexed column are different.

questionContent.body: Which clause is required when creating an updatable view

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: WITH CHECK OPTION ensures that updates through the view do not violate the viewâ€™s WHERE condition.

questionContent.body: What happens if the underlying table structure of a view changes (e.g., a column is dropped)

questionOptions.body: The view updates with default values

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: If a view references a dropped column, it becomes invalid and will produce an error when accessed.

questionContent.body: What is the primary purpose of using a join index in a database

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: ALTER VIEW is used to redefine an existing view.

questionContent.body: What is the primary purpose of using a join index in a database

questionOptions.body: To optimize the execution of join operations
To store the results of join operations permanently
To restrict the types of joins that can be performed

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: A join index is used to optimize the execution of join operations by maintaining a precomputed index of join results, improving query performance.

questionContent.body: When might you choose to use a NATURAL JOIN over an INNER JOIN

questionOptions.body: When you want to explicitly define the join condition
When the tables have columns with the same name and you want to automatically join on those columns
When you need to include all rows from both tables regardless of matching
When you want to join rows within the same table

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: NATURAL JOIN automatically joins tables based on columns with the same name, simplifying the query when such columns exist.

questionContent.body: Which of the following strategies can help improve the performance of join operations

questionOptions.body: Adding indexes on the columns used in the join condition
Using FULL OUTER JOIN for all join operations
Avoiding the use of WHERE clauses

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Adding indexes on the columns used in the join condition can significantly improve the performance of join operations by allowing the database to quickly locate the rows to be joined.

questionContent.body: Given tables Orders (Order ID, Customer ID) and Customers (Customer ID, Name), write a query to find all customers and the number of orders they have placed, including those who have not placed any orders.

questionOptions.body: SELECT Customers.  Name, COUNT (Orders. Order ID) FROM Customers LEFT JOIN Orders ON Customers. Customer ID = Orders. Customer ID GROUP BY Customers. Name
SELECT Customers. Name, COUNT (Orders. Order ID) FROM Customers RIGHT JOIN Orders ON Customers. Customer ID = Orders. Customer ID GROUP BY Customers. Name
SELECT Customers. Name, COUNT (Orders. Order ID) FROM Customers INNER JOIN Orders ON Customers. Customer ID = Orders. Customer ID GROUP BY Customers. Name
SELECT Customers. Name, COUNT (Orders. Order ID) FROM Customers FULL OUTER JOIN Orders ON Customers. Customer ID = Orders. Customer ID GROUP BY Customers. Name

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: LEFT JOIN ensures all customers are included, even those who have not placed any orders. COUNT (Orders. Order ID) will return 0 for customers without orders.

questionContent.body: How would you write a query to return all products and their respective categories, ensuring that products without categories are still included

questionOptions.body: SELECT * FROM Products INNER JOIN Categories ON Products. Category ID = Categories.ID
SELECT * FROM Products LEFT JOIN Categories ON Products. Category ID = Categories.ID
SELECT * FROM Products RIGHT JOIN Categories ON Products. Category ID = Categories.ID
SELECT * FROM Products FULL OUTER JOIN Categories ON Products. Category ID = Categories.ID

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: LEFT JOIN ensures all products are included, with NULLs for categories where there are no matches.

questionContent.body: Given two tables A and B, how would you write a query to get all rows from A and only matching rows from B, filling NULLs for non-matching rows

questionOptions.body: SELECT * FROM A INNER JOIN B ON A.ID = B.ID
SELECT * FROM A LEFT JOIN B ON A.ID = B.ID
SELECT * FROM A RIGHT JOIN B ON A.ID = B.ID
SELECT * FROM A FULL OUTER JOIN B ON A.ID = B.ID

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: LEFT JOIN returns all rows from the left table (A) and the matching rows from the right table (B), filling NULLs for non-matching rows.

questionContent.body: Which of the following SQL queries will correctly use a RIGHT JOIN to include all rows from the second table (Table B) and matching rows from the first table (Table A)

questionOptions.body: SELECT * FROM A LEFT JOIN B ON A.ID = B.ID
SELECT * FROM A RIGHT JOIN B ON A.ID = B.ID
SELECT * FROM A FULL OUTER JOIN B ON A.ID = B.ID
SELECT * FROM A INNER JOIN B ON A.ID = B.ID

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: RIGHT JOIN returns all rows from the right table (B) and the matching rows from the left table (A).

questionContent.body: What will be the result of the following query if some employees do not have matching department records? SELECT Employees. Name, Departments. Name FROM Employees LEFT JOIN Departments ON Employees. Dept ID = Departments ID

questionOptions.body: All employees and their departments, with NULLs for unmatched departments.
All departments and their employees, with NULLs for unmatched employees.

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: LEFT JOIN returns all rows from the left table (Employees) and the matched rows from the right table (Departments). For employees without matching departments, the department columns will be NULL.

questionContent.body: If Table A has 10 rows and Table B has 20 rows, what is the maximum number of rows that can be returned by a LEFT JOIN

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: LEFT JOIN returns all rows from the left table (A) and the matching rows from the right table (B). The maximum number of rows in the result will be equal to the number of rows in the left table (10), plus any additional rows from the right table if they match the join condition.

questionContent.body: Given two tables A (with 8 rows) and B (with 5 rows), and assuming there are no matching values between the tables, how many rows will a FULL OUTER JOIN return

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: FULL OUTER JOIN will return all rows from both tables. Since there are no matches, it will include all 8 rows from A and all 5 rows from B, resulting in 8 + 5 = 13 rows.

questionContent.body: Consider two tables: Employees and Departments. Which SQL query will return all departments and only those employees who are assigned to a department

questionOptions.body: SELECT * FROM Employees FULL OUTER JOIN Departments ON Employees. Dept ID = Departments.ID
SELECT * FROM Employees LEFT JOIN Departments ON Employees. Dept ID = Departments.ID
SELECT * FROM Employees RIGHT JOIN Departments ON Employees. Dept ID = Departments.ID
SELECT * FROM Employees INNER JOIN Departments ON Employees. DeptID = Departments.ID

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: RIGHT JOIN returns all rows from the right table (Departments) and the matching rows from the left table (Employees).

questionContent.body: Which SQL statement retrieves the highest value in a column

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: The `SELECT MAX(column_name) FROM table_name;` statement retrieves the highest value in a column.

questionContent.body: How can you select the second highest salary from the employees table

questionOptions.body: SELECT salary FROM employees ORDER BY salary DESC LIMIT 1 OFFSET 1
SELECT salary FROM employees ORDER BY salary ASC LIMIT 1 OFFSET 1
SELECT MAX(salary) FROM employees WHERE salary < (SELECT MAX(salary) FROM employees)

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: The correct query to select the second highest salary is `SELECT MAX(salary) FROM employees WHERE salary < (SELECT MAX(salary) FROM employees);

questionContent.body: How do you delete duplicate rows in a table while keeping one instance of each

questionOptions.body: DELETE FROM table_name a WHERE a.id > (SELECT MIN(b.id) FROM table_name b WHERE a.col1 = b.col1)

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: This query deletes duplicate rows by keeping the row with the minimum id for each unique value.

questionContent.body: How do you change the data type of the PhoneNumber column in the Employees table to VARCHAR(20)

questionOptions.body: MODIFY TABLE Employees ALTER COLUMN PhoneNumber VARCHAR(20)
ALTER TABLE Employees MODIFY COLUMN PhoneNumber VARCHAR(20)
UPDATE TABLE Employees SET PhoneNumber VARCHAR(20)
ALTER TABLE Employees CHANGE COLUMN PhoneNumber VARCHAR(20)

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: The correct syntax to change a column's data type is `ALTER TABLE table_name MODIFY COLUMN column_name new_data_type;

questionContent.body: What will the following SQL statement do INSERT INTO Employees (Name) VALUES ('Jane')

questionOptions.body: Inserts Jane into all columns of the Employees table
Inserts Jane into the Name column of the Employees table
Updates the Name column of the Employees table with Jane
Deletes Jane from the Name column of the Employees table

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: This statement inserts 'Jane' into the `Name` column of the `Employees` table.

questionContent.body: Which of the following statements correctly retrieves all unique values from the Department column of the Employees table

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: `SELECT DISTINCT column_name` retrieves all unique values from the specified column.

questionContent.body: What is the correct syntax to update the Salary of employees to 5000 where Department is HR

questionOptions.body: MODIFY Employees SET Salary=5000 WHERE Department=HR
UPDATE Employees SET Salary=5000 WHERE Department=HR
CHANGE Employees SET Salary=5000 WHERE Department=HR
ALTER Employees SET Salary=5000 WHERE Department=HR

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: The correct syntax for updating data is `UPDATE table_name SET column1=value1 WHERE condition;`

questionContent.body: How do you delete a record from the `Employees` table where the EmployeeID is 10

questionOptions.body: DELETE EmployeeID FROM Employees WHERE ID=10

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: The correct syntax to delete a specific record is `DELETE FROM table_name WHERE condition;`

questionContent.body: What is the correct syntax to insert a new record into the Employees table

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: The correct syntax for inserting a new record is `INSERT INTO table_name (columns) VALUES (values);

questionContent.body:
Assume:
A(id, value)
B(id, description)
What does this query return
[text=code]
SELECT * FROM A JOIN B USING(id);

questionOptions.body: Join using common 'id' and eliminates one 'id' column
Same as ON clause but keeps both id columns

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: USING clause joins on the column(s) specified and outputs only one copy of that column.

questionContent.body: If A has 3 rows and B has 2 matching rows per A.id, how many rows will the query return

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: For each A.id, 2 matching B rows â†’ 3 Ã— 2 = 6 total rows.

questionContent.body: What does this query return

<svg width="556" height="100"
     xml:space='preserve'
     xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"
     xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">
<text x="40" y="40" >1 | SELECT & FROM A NATURAL JOIN B</text>
</svg>

questionOptions.body: All rows from A and B where all columns match
All rows from A and B where columns with same name match
Error if no common columns exist

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: NATURAL JOIN relies on columns with the same name. If none exist, it raises an error.

questionContent.body:
Given:

Table A has 3 rows

Table B has 0 rows

What will the result count be for:

<svg width="752" height="100"
     xml:space='preserve'
     xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"
     xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">
<text x="40" y="40" >1 | SELECT & FROM A INNER JOIN B ON A.sd ? B.sd;</text>
</svg>

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: INNER JOIN only returns matched rows. Since B is empty, no matches â€” zero rows returned.

questionContent.body: What will be the result of the following query

<svg width="990" height="100"
     xml:space='preserve'
     xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"
     xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">
<text x="40" y="40" >1 | SELECT & FROM A LEFT JOIN B ON A.sd ? B.sd WHERE B.sd IS NULL</text>
</svg>

questionOptions.body: All rows from A and matching rows from B
All rows from A that have no match in B
All rows from B with no match in A
An error due to WHERE clause

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: LEFT JOIN returns all rows from A. The WHERE condition filters only those where B.id is NULL â€” i.e., unmatched rows from A.

questionContent.body: Which UPDATE is correct with a JOIN

questionOptions.body: UPDATE t1 JOIN t2 ON t1.id = t2.id SET t1.val = t2.val
UPDATE t1 SET val = t2.val FROM t2 WHERE t1.id = t2.id
UPDATE t1 FROM t2 SET val = t2.val WHERE t1.id = t2.id
UPDATE t1 SET val = t2.val JOIN t2 ON t1.id = t2.id

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: A is MySQL-style syntax for UPDATE with JOIN.

questionContent.body:
What is the result of this
[tpe=code]
INSERT INTO emp_log(emp_id, action)
SELECT emp_id, 'FIRED' FROM employees WHERE status = 'terminated'

questionOptions.body: Error if emp_log has no default for timestamp

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Valid INSERT using SELECT.

questionContent.body: Consider

<svg width="1102" height="120"
     xml:space='preserve'
     xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"
     xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">
<text x="40" y="40" >1 | UPDATE employeei</text>
<text x="40" y="60" >2 | SET dept_sd ? (SELECT dept_sd FROM departmenti WHERE locatson ? 'NY')</text>
</svg>
What happens if subquery returns more than one row

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Scalar subqueries must return exactly one value; else it errors.

questionContent.body: Given a table employees(emp_id INT, salary INT), what does the following query do

<svg width="808" height="120"
     xml:space='preserve'
     xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"
     xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">
<text x="40" y="40" >1 | UPDATE employeei</text>
<text x="40" y="60" >2 | SET ialary ? (SELECT MAX(ialary) FROM employeei)</text>
</svg>

questionOptions.body: Sets all salaries to the maximum salary
Syntax error due to scalar subquery
Sets only NULL salaries to max salary

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Scalar subquery is valid and assigns max salary to all rows.

questionContent.body: Which of the following SQL statements correctly inserts rows from one table into another with a WHERE clause and ignores duplicates based on a unique constraint

questionOptions.body: INSERT INTO emp_archive SELECT * FROM employees WHERE dept_id = 10
INSERT IGNORE INTO emp_archive SELECT * FROM employees WHERE dept_id = 10
INSERT INTO emp_archive SELECT DISTINCT * FROM employees WHERE dept_id = 10
INSERT INTO emp_archive SELECT * FROM employees WHERE dept_id = 10 ON DUPLICATE KEY IGNORE

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: INSERT IGNORE skips rows that would violate constraints like UNIQUE.

questionContent.body: Which scenario would benefit the most from a filtered index in SQL Server

questionOptions.body: Large table queried by multiple users
Column used in every WHERE clause
Sparse data where only rows meeting specific criteria are queried

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Filtered indexes improve performance and reduce size for queries targeting a subset of data.

questionContent.body: Which of the following can cause index fragmentation in SQL Server

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Frequent DML operations can lead to logical fragmentation, making indexes less efficient.

questionContent.body: In which situation would a bitmap index outperform a B-tree index

questionOptions.body: Column with 3 distinct values and large table
Small table with low update frequency

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Bitmap indexes excel on low-cardinality columns in large, read-mostly datasets. They perform poorly in high-update environments.

questionContent.body: Which type of index is best suited for high cardinality columns in a large table with frequent SELECT queries

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Non-clustered indexes are ideal for high cardinality columns because they maintain a separate structure that allows fast retrieval without affecting data storage order.

questionContent.body: Which isolation level is most appropriate in a stored procedure designed to prevent dirty reads but allow phantom reads

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: READ COMMITTED prevents dirty reads but allows non-repeatable and phantom reads.

questionContent.body: Which statement allows dynamic SQL execution inside a stored procedure in SQL Server

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: EXEC() or sp_executesql is used for dynamic SQL in SQL Server.

questionContent.body: What will happen if a stored procedure is executed without a required input parameter

questionOptions.body: Execution will continue with default values
The procedure skips the parameter logic

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Missing required parameters trigger an error unless default values are specified.

questionContent.body: What is the benefit of marking a function as SCHEMABINDING in SQL Server

questionOptions.body: Prevents underlying objects from being altered

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: SCHEMABINDING locks referenced objects, preventing drops or structure changes.

questionContent.body: Which type of user-defined function can return a table and be used like a table in a FROM clause

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Inline TVFs can be treated as tables and have performance benefits over multi-statement functions.

questionContent.body: Which of the following is true about scalar user-defined functions in SQL Server

questionOptions.body: Cannot be used in SELECT clauses
Can be called from CHECK constraints

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Scalar UDFs can be used in constraints, but cannot perform DML operations.

questionContent.body: Which of the following is true about indexed (materialized) views in SQL Server

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Indexed views are physically stored and maintained like tables.

questionContent.body: In SQL Server, which clause ensures that all inserts or updates through a view adhere to the logic of the viewâ€™s SELECT statement

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: WITH CHECK OPTION ensures DML operations through the view do not violate the view's WHERE clause.

questionContent.body: Consider the relations r1(P, Q, R) and r2(R, S, T) with primary keys P and R respectively. The relation r1 contains 2000 tuples and r2 contains 2500 tuples. The maximum size of the join r1â‹ˆ r2 is :

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Explanation: the maximum size of the join is determined by the number of tuples in the larger relation, r2, since each tuple in r2 can match with at most one tuple in r1.

questionContent.body:
Consider the following relation schema pertaining to a students database

Student (roll no, name, address)
Enroll (roll no, course no, course name)

where the primary keys are roll no, course no. The number of tuples in the Student and Enroll tables are 120 and 8 respectively. What are the maximum and minimum number of tuples that can be present in (Student * Enroll), where '*' denotes natural join

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: The maximum number of tuples in the natural join result is 960, occurring when each student is enrolled in each course, and the minimum is 120, corresponding to the number of tuples in the smaller Enroll table.

questionContent.body:
Consider the relational schema below
Suppliers(sid:integer, sname:string, city:string, street:string)
Parts(pid:integer, pname:string, color:string)
Catalog(sid:integer, pid:integer, cost:real)
On the database as mentioned above, consider the following relational query

<svg width="1144" height="220"
     xml:space='preserve'
     xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"
     xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">
<text x="40" y="40" >1 | SELECT S.iname</text>
<text x="40" y="60" >2 |     FROM Supplseri S</text>
<text x="40" y="80" >v |         WHERE S.isd NOT IN (SELECT C.isd</text>
<text x="40" y="100" >4 |                             FROM Catalog C</text>
<text x="40" y="120" >5 |                             WHERE C.psd NOT IN (SELECT P.psd </text>
<text x="40" y="140" >6 |                                                 FROM Parti P</text>
<text x="40" y="160" >+ |                                                 WHERE P.color<> 'blue'))</text>
</svg>

questionOptions.body: Find out who has supplied a non-blue part.
Look up the names of all the vendors who haven't delivered a non-blue part.
Find all of the vendors who have supplied blue components exclusively.
Find all of the suppliers who haven't supplied blue parts exclusively.

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
Because the specified query returns suppliers who have not supplied any blue components, the (D) option matched, which means it can have sections that aren't blue.
1.	False because this might include blue portions and "null" components.
(B) Untrue, as it returns something other than a blue portion.
(C) False, as this is not returned.

questionContent.body: Take a look at the collection of relationships below,

<svg width="822" height="140"
     xml:space='preserve'
     xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"
     xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">
<text x="40" y="40" >1 | Studenti: (Roll_number, Name, Date_of_bsrth)</text>
<text x="40" y="60" >2 | Couriei: (Courie number, Courie_name, Initructor)</text>
<text x="40" y="80" >v | Gradei: (Roll_number, Courie_number, Grade)</text>
</svg>
as well as the SQL query that follows.

<svg width="1060" height="240"
     xml:space='preserve'
     xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"
     xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">
<text x="40" y="40" >1 | ielect dsitsnct Name</text>
<text x="40" y="60" >2 |              from Studenti, Couriei, Gradei</text>
<text x="40" y="80" >v |              where Studenti. Roll_number ? Gradei.Roll_number</text>
<text x="40" y="100" >4 |                   and Couriei.Initructor ? Korth</text>
<text x="40" y="120" >5 |                   and Couriei.Courie_number ? Gradei.Courie_number</text>
<text x="40" y="140" >6 |                   and Gradei.grade ? A</text>
<text x="40" y="160" >+ |  [type?te%t]</text>
<text x="40" y="180" >8 | The abo3e query computei whsch of the followsng ieti</text>
</svg>

questionOptions.body: Names of students who have received an A in all of Korth's classes.
Names of students who received an A in all of their classes
Names of students who have received an A in at least one of Korth's courses.

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Since there is an â€˜andâ€™ on the query predicate, the query returns the names of all students who have received an "A" grade and attend Korth's courses, i.e., at least one of them.

questionContent.body: Null values are viewed as unknown in SQL, and comparisons with null values are treated as unknown. Assume that all comparisons with a null value are false. Which of the following pairings does not have the same meaning

questionOptions.body: x = 5 AND x> 4 and x < 6, where x is an integer

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Because a comparison with a NULL value is always False in the provided query, "x â‰  5" will be false. "x = 5" will also return false, and not (x = 5) = not(false) = true will also return true. As a result, these aren't equal pairs.

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: 10 rows are returned if you select a name from those over the age of 21. 7 rows are returned if you choose Name among persons with a height of more than 180. Select Name from People where (Age > 21) or (Height > 180) will return 10 rows since there is a choice between the two conditions.

questionContent.body:
The relation scheme below stores information on a company's workers, where empId is the key and deptId is the employee's assigned department. Each employee has a specific department allocated to them.
emp(empId, name, gender, salary, deptId)
Consider the SQL query below:

<svg width="1102" height="160"
     xml:space='preserve'
     xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"
     xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">
<text x="40" y="40" >1 | ielect deptId, count(&)</text>
<text x="40" y="60" >2 | from emp</text>
<text x="40" y="80" >v | where gender ? â€œfemaleâ€ and ialary > (ielect a3g(ialary)from emp)</text>
<text x="40" y="100" >4 | group by deptId;</text>
</svg>
The above query returns, for each department, the number of female workers whose salary is higher than the company's average salary of

questionOptions.body: All female employees in the department
All female employees in the company

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: The inner query (select avg(salary) from emp) runs on the whole emp table, i.e., all employees.

questionContent.body: What is a View in SQL

questionOptions.body: A virtual table based on the result of a SELECT query
A physical table in the database

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: A view is a virtual table that presents data from one or more tables using a SELECT statement. It doesn't store data itself.

questionContent.body: What is a key benefit of using stored procedures

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Stored procedures help improve performance and allow better control over access to data.

questionContent.body: Which of the following cannot be used to update data directly

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Views based on multiple tables or complex joins are usually not updatable directly.

questionContent.body: Can a view be used to simplify complex queries

questionOptions.body: Only if it has an index

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Views can encapsulate complex joins and queries, making it easier to access data.

questionContent.body: Which SQL object allows you to pass parameters and return a single value

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: A function in SQL can accept input parameters and must return a single value.

questionContent.body: What is a Stored Procedure in SQL

questionOptions.body: A precompiled collection of SQL statements
A table that stores old records

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: A stored procedure is a set of SQL statements that can be saved and executed repeatedly.

questionContent.body: Which of the following is true about indexes in SQL

questionOptions.body: They help speed up data retrieval
They are used to delete data faster

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Indexes improve the speed of data retrieval operations by creating pointers to data in a table.

questionContent.body: What is the output of this query

<svg width="1284" height="100"
     xml:space='preserve'
     xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"
     xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">
<text x="40" y="40" >1 | SELECT department FROM departmenti WHERE sd NOT IN (SELECT dept_sd FROM employeei)</text>
</svg>

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: The subquery gets dept_id values from the employees table, and the outer query returns departments not present in that list â€” i.e., departments with no employees.

questionContent.body: Which keyword allows a subquery to return multiple rows

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: IN is used when the subquery returns multiple values to compare with the outer query.

questionContent.body:
What will the following SQL do
[tpye=code]
SELECT name FROM employees WHERE dept_id = (SELECT id FROM departments WHERE name = 'Sales')

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: The subquery finds the dept_id of the 'Sales' department, and the outer query selects employees belonging to that department.

questionContent.body: What type of subquery returns a single value

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: A scalar subquery returns exactly one value (one row and one column).

questionContent.body: Where can subqueries be used

questionOptions.body: n SELECT, FROM, and WHERE clauses

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Subqueries can be used in multiple places like SELECT, FROM, and WHERE clauses to return data based on other queries.

questionContent.body: What is the purpose of the HAVING clause in SQL

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: The HAVING clause is used to filter groups after the GROUP BY clause is applied.

questionContent.body: You are developing a reporting system for a healthcare organization that tracks patient appointments and medical procedures. The database consists of several tables, including patients, appointments, and procedures. You need to retrieve a list of all patients along with their appointment details and any associated medical procedures. Which type of join would you use to combine the appointment and procedure data
What type of join should you use to retrieve a list of all patients along with their appointment    details and any associated medical procedures

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Using a Full Outer Join between the appointments and procedures tables ensures that all appointment details and associated medical procedures are included in the result set, providing a comprehensive view of patient appointments and procedures.

questionContent.body: You need to compare data from the sales table and the product inventory table to analyze product sales performance. Which type of join would be most appropriate for this task

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: An Inner Join retrieves data where matching records exist between the sales table and the product inventory table, allowing for analysis of product sales performance based on available inventory.

questionContent.body: Even though some employees might not be assigned to any department, what form of join would you typically use if you were tasked with extracting all employees and their department names in a SQL query

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: might use a Left Join to ensure all employees are returned, even if they are not assigned to any department. This would enable Infosys to retrieve employee details along with their respective department names, with NULL values for employees not assigned to any department.

questionContent.body: Which of the following statement is TRUE about FULL OUTER JOIN created on two tables Table1 and Table2

questionOptions.body: Retrieves all the unmatched rows of Table1
Retrieves all the unmatched rows of Table2
Retrieves both matched and unmatched rows of Table1 and Table2
Retrieves only matched rows of table1 and Table2

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: The statement is TRUE about FULL OUTER JOIN created on two tables Table1 and Table2 is Retrieves both matched and unmatched rows of Table1 and Table2.

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: When a CROSS JOIN is achieved between R1 and R2, 0 tuples the resultant set will have.

questionContent.body: How do a left join and a right join vary from one another

questionOptions.body: Right join returns all records from both tables, while left join returns only matching records.
Left join returns all records from both tables, while Right join returns only matching records.
Left join returns all records from the left table and the matched records from the right table, while right join returns all records from the right table and the matched records from the left table.
There is no difference; they both return all records from both tables.

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: The key difference between left join and right join is the table from which all records are retained. Left join retains all records from the left table and the matched records from the right table, while right join retains all records from the right table and the matched records from the left table.

questionContent.body: What occurs in the scenario that a SQL query is executed without a join condition

questionOptions.body: The query returns only rows where the join condition is not met.
The query returns all possible combinations of rows from the joined tables.
The query returns only rows where the join condition is met.

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: If you don't specify a join condition, SQL will return all possible combinations of rows from the joined tables, which can result in a large Cartesian product. This is usually not desired and can lead to performance issues.

questionContent.body: How do you delete all the rows from a table without deleting the table itself

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: The TRUNCATE TABLE statement removes all rows from a table without deleting the table itself.

questionContent.body: Which SQL statement is used to retrieve records that match a specified pattern

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: The `LIKE` keyword is used to retrieve records that match a specified pattern.

questionContent.body: Which keyword is used to add multiple rows in a single INSERT statement

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: The `VALUES` keyword is used to add multiple rows in a single INSERT statement by separating each row with commas.

questionContent.body: How do you add a column to an existing table

questionOptions.body:
ALTER TABLE ADD COLUMN        

[key=D                                                        
MODIFY TABLE ADD COLUMN

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: The ALTER TABLE ADD COLUMN statement is used to add a new column to an existing table.

questionContent.body: How do you sort the result set of a query in ascending order

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: The ORDER BY clause sorts the result set in ascending order when used with ASC.

questionContent.body: Which SQL clause is used to filter records

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: The WHERE clause is used to filter records based on specific conditions.

questionContent.body: How do you select all columns from a table named students

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: The * symbol selects all columns from the specified table.

questionContent.body: Which SQL statement is used to retrieve data from a database

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: The SELECT statement is used to fetch data from a database.
